Title: the conjugal conjecture

Scene: need to understand it, I just need to be grateful. I love you, Penny.
But something wonderful did come from our relationship. That young man right there.
Sheldon: Leonard? Leonard?
You realize you and I could become brothers.
I hope you’re right. ‘Cause a grown man living with his brother and his brother’s wife is weird.
Okay. Do you think your father’s doing unspeakable things to my mother?
Are you saying that because the things are unspeakable?
Very well.
Hey, if you want me to sleep you’re gonna have to stop talking.
It was nice of her to show us playing dumb with an example.
Whuh, are we still doing the dumb thing? Okay, why, what’s wrong?
Oh, golly, however did he humiliate you?
Do I say stop what, or just throw in the towel?
Oh, excuse me, that is my mother you’re talking about, however accurately.
And turned their phones off.
You know, also, if they did have coitus, we’ll all be needing a skilled psychiatrist.
All right, so less or equally awkward, got it.
Hello.
So, did you defile my mother or not?
Did that conversation include the phrase your genitals are a joy to behold?
Or what a joy it is to behold my genitals.
A man named Jesus convinced you to build a church in Africa. You’re kind of a sucker.
What? In the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia? I can’t be the only one that knows that’s halfway.
What? But he’s a mediocre academic. And according to Beverley, his sexual prowess is sub-par. He’s basically Leonard with a bigger prostate.
Yes, while also getting in a solid dig at you. Pretty efficient, huh?
But why should you get to go and leave me here with your bickering parents?
Great, now I have to start all over.
You made God sad today, Mom.
Well, that’s still no reason to rush into anything. I mean, look at us. We took things remarkably slow. You and I, we didn’t even hold hands for two years.
Hey, hey. She’s mine, take a cold shower, grandpa.
Why do people cry at weddings?
Speaking of love, STDs among the elderly are skyrocketing.
Yeah, excuse me, I need to say something to someone pretty special, and I just can’t wait any longer.

Leonard, you and I have our ups and downs. But I have always considered you my family. Even before the recent threat of our parents fornicating like wrinkly old rabbits. I don’t always show it, but you are of great importance to me. Both of you.
Plenty of time for you to meet another geriatric boy toy.
Yes ma’am.
Well, and you need to drive the car and mind your business.
What, you’re not my mother.
Yes ma’am.
Leonard: What?
We’re not gonna be brothers. We’re not gonna be stepbrothers. Go to sleep.
Go to sleep.
No.
I’m sorry if this stuff is gonna make the ceremony awkward.
Yeah, drive safe.
Well, why? What’s wrong?
Not helping, buddy. Mother, Penny and I really want you to be part of this. Please stay.
Here you are, Mother.
I’m glad you decided to stay. It’s gonna be special for Penny and me to share this with you.
Yeah, special, like that. (Knock on door) That’s them. Please don’t make things any more awkward than they already are.
Hey, guys, come on in.
You don’t know his girlfriend very well.
Well, nothing happened, right? It’s over. Until we get married a third time, you guys will never have to see each other again.
Mary, I’m sorry you’re in the middle of this.
Are you saying that my dad’s not good enough for your mom?
This is ridiculous. I’m going across the hall.
Fine, then you go.
That still leaves me here with him.
Hello.
Oh, you, too. Hey, everyone, this is my mother, Beverley.
And he can’t wait to meet you, too. Can I get anyone a drink?
Penny, as a scientist, my job is to figure out why things happen. But I don’t think I’ll ever understand how someone like me could get to be with someone like you. You know, maybe I don’t
Thank you.
Hey, I’m just thrilled we’re all getting along for a minute.
That’s okay. I can make it over.
That was almost a minute.
Penny: God, I thought my brother fresh out of jail was gonna make everyone uncomfortable, but now this.
Okay, I’m gonna go pick up my family. Like an hour and half, two hours, depending on traffic.

Oh, hey, and do yourself a favour, all right? When Beverly gets here, do not bring up last night. All right? As far as you’re concerned, you don’t know anything, you didn’t see anything. I want you just to play dumb.
What? Oh. Hi. Okay, hey there, I got, I’m sorry, I got to go now.
Why?
Okay, Beverley, aren’t you overreacting a little? All we know is they shared a cab and had a nightcap.
Yeah, plus if you leave, Alfred will know he got under your skin.
Oh, I can’t wait for you to meet everyone. I told them all about you.
Uh, not everything, just, like, the jail and drugs part.
What?
Well, Mom, I’m sorry, but…
So, uh, Randall, can’t believe after all these years you finally get to visit me in California.
All right, you guys, uh, get settled in, then we’ll go across the hall and say hi to everyone.
I thought it was really funny.
Okay. Listen, Mom, I know you’re nervous, but I promise you, no one is gonna judge you or this family.
Pretty good. I actually just got assigned a much better territory.
Well, I learned from the best.
Aw.
Hey.
Hey. Is everyone getting to know each other?

Okay, I understand everyone’s a little tense today, so I am just gonna get to the important stuff. Leonard, standing here with you in front of our family and friends is bringing up a lot of feelings. Like what a good idea it was to elope the first time. But also how incredibly happy you make me. Thank you for marrying me. Hopefully for the last time.
Oh.
Oh.
Oh, thanks, Mom.
Is he? I never noticed.
Beverley: I wanted to thank you for going through all the trouble of planning a second wedding ceremony for me, but unfortunately I cannot attend.
I just cannot stay here while your father goes out of his way to humiliate me.
I don’t see why I should have to watch your father parade around with some bible-thumping bumpkin.
I can’t wait for this day to be over.
You’re not seriously going to visit each other.
Oh please, you’re just saying this to antagonize me.
So, what do you do for a living?
Thank you for taking us to the airport.
Water under the bridge, Alfred. Leonard, why don’t you get into the carpool lane?
No, no, let’s plod along. It’ll make your father feel more comfortable.
Do the world a favour, and don’t wake up tomorrow morning.
Raj: It is funny when you think about it.
Hello.
Howard Wolowitz?
Address?
Um, no.
May I ask what this is about?
Very well.
Okay.
That’s not him.
What are you talking about? They’ve always known where you live.
Can we take a moment to discuss that I just lied to the government for you?
Hey, make sure you tell him that you weren’t home when he came by and that your Indian friend gave you the message the moment you stepped through the door.
Oh, I take it back, don’t mention me.
That’s what he said to me.
Calm down, okay? Try not to think about it.
You know that hurts my feelings.
Okay.
Oh, come on. What’s the worst that could come of this meeting?

Okay, that’s not so bad. You know what happened to the scientists that worked on the Manhattan Project? The government forced them to move to the desert. They had to live in secret, and when Oppenheimer objected to what they made him do, they destroyed his reputation.

I just read a book about Oppenheimer, seemed like a chance to show off. (Howard laughs) There he is, there’s my happy Hebraic homeboy. Yeah, that’s the smile I’m gonna remember when you’re living in the desert and I’m living with your wife.
Howard: Maybe to you. You didn’t get a $500 traffic ticket.
Hey, if thinking secret government agents are chasing you makes you a lunatic, then, yeah, okay.
I have performance anxiety. You of all people should know that.
That’s great, now they know where I live.
Yeah. I would not have done that for you.
Yes, hello. Uh, this is Howard Wolowitz for Colonel Richard Williams.

Hi, Colonel Williams, how can I help you? What? Oh, uh, yes, he is from India. No, I don’t know his immigration status. Relax, I’m still on hold. Speaking. Okay, sure, I can meet with you on Thursday. Caltech is fine. Yeah, and may I ask what this is about? I may not?
Why wouldn’t that colonel say what the meeting’s about? It has to be bad news.
Calm down, try not to think about it.
Why do I bother talking to you?
I don’t know. They take the invention away, and I get nothing?
What’s the point of that story?
At least she’s yelling at someone else for a change.
Bernadette: Because you were driving like a lunatic.
It didn’t help that you couldn’t walk a straight line when the cop pulled you over.
Yeah, if you want to go off the grid, you have to move out of your mother’s house.

We’re here today to celebrate love.

Well, quit it.
All right, that’s enough jail talk.

Not funny, Wyatt.
Well, fine, if everyone wants to make jokes about our problems, then I can, too. Knock, knock. Who’s there? Our family is an embarrassment.

Hi.

You’re done. He’s done.

Although that Sheldon is a bit peculiar.
Wyatt (Penny\u2019s father): Hey, look, they got Walgreens here, too.
Wyatt: Just trying to make this a happy trip, dear.
He was cooking and selling crystal meth, Susan, I think we can let the cigarettes slide.
Well, he probably buys his illegal drugs from a local vendor.
So how’s the world of pharmaceuticals treating you?
Penny drinks more than I do.
It’s nice to meet the woman who raised this fine young man. I’m looking forward to meeting his father.
Well, I could use another beer.
Welcome to the family, Leonard. Don’t lend your new brother-in-law money.

Yes, I am. I’m just feeling a little guilty about all the trouble I’ve caused.

Well, I don’t want to stay here with her. I’ll go.
They’re practicing for what’s coming later.
